awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Comprehensive monitoring of protein interaction networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The genome encodes information for thousands of proteins, which form the building blocks of cellular machinery in all organisms. Proteins normally do not function in isolation, but rather in multi-component complexes, such that most vital cellular functions are governed by essential interactions between proteins. These protein interaction networks are dynamic, and changes in the interactions are the major cause of physiological and pathological changes in cellular and organismal function. Thus, it is essential to have universal and easily implementable tools that allow scientists to measure the dynamics of protein interactions. This project aims to develop such a tool, which will allow researchers to simultaneously map dynamic protein interactions for up to hundreds of proteins under many conditions. This novel approach will address many key issues in biology, such as which interaction changes drive developmental decisions or occur due to mutations that lead to pathological outcomes. Moreover, the project has high potential to advance biotechnology, for example, by making it possible to systematically screen drug candidates for the ability to specifically disrupt protein interactions that drive a disease state. The project also provides cross-disciplinary research training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.

The project will employ a new antibody and sequencing-based strategy in order to map protein interactions and their changes. There are two fundamental components to the strategy. First, antibodies are uniquely “barcoded” by a short DNA sequence so that each antibody – and by extension, its target protein – can be easily identified by next-generation sequencing. Second, a combinatorial barcoding strategy, via a spilt and pool procedure, adds unique combinatorial DNA sequences to the barcoded antibodies. Only antibodies co-bound to the same protein complex will get the same combinatorial barcode and protein interactions can be reconstructed by sequencing and matching these barcodes. In summary, this project aims to provide a facile approach to directly study protein interaction dynamics at high throughput, but at the same time at single complex resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The genome contains information for thousands of proteins, which are the building blocks of cellular machinery in all living organisms. Proteins usually don’t work alone; they operate in large groups, and essential cellular functions depend on interactions between these proteins. These protein interaction networks are dynamic, meaning they can change, and these changes are often the main reason for physiological (normal) and pathological (disease-related) changes in cells and organisms. Therefore, it’s crucial to have easy-to-use tools that allow scientists to measure how protein interactions change over time. This project aimed to develop such a tool, which we called CITY-seq. CITY-seq would enable researchers to map how proteins interact dynamically, allowing them to study hundreds of proteins under various conditions at the same time.

Our approach used a new strategy based on antibodies and sequencing to track protein interactions. This strategy has two main components. First, we "barcode" antibodies with a short DNA sequence, making it easy to identify each antibody—and its corresponding protein—using next-generation sequencing. Second, we use a combinatorial barcoding method, where a unique combination of DNA sequences is added to the barcoded antibodies. Only antibodies that are bound to the same protein complex will share the same combinatorial barcode, allowing us to reconstruct protein interactions through sequencing and matching these barcodes. This project has great potential to advance biotechnology, such as enabling systematic screening of drug candidates that can disrupt disease-causing protein interactions. Additionally, the project provided valuable cross-disciplinary research training for both graduate and undergraduate students.

 

Results

Intellectual Merit

After two years of work on CITY-seq, we are unsure if it will achieve the high throughput we initially hoped for in studying protein-protein interactions (PPIs) at the level of single complexes. However, this work has led to two exciting new results and projects.

First, we found that our barcoding strategy allows us to map how proteins and RNA molecules interact at the level of individual nucleotides. This ability has enabled us to identify several RNA-binding proteins (RBPs) associated with ribosomes at a high structural resolution. For example, we discovered that LARP1, a key protein involved in regulating translation through the mTOR signaling pathway, binds directly to the mRNA entry channel. This finding helps explain why LARP1 inhibits translation. We confirmed this interaction and its exact location using cryo-electron microscopy (cryoEM). We are now using this method to investigate how dozens of RBPs interact with the ribosome at high structural resolution and how these interactions vary under different conditions.

Additionally, while checking the specificity of the antibodies used for CITY-seq, we found that we can cleverly pool antibodies together to enhance immunoprecipitation-mass spectrometry (IP-MS) experiments. This pooling increases the throughput of IP-MS for studying PPIs by a factor of 20. A PhD student is currently running key experiments to explore this new approach in greater detail.

In summary, although CITY-seq did not fully develop as we originally planned, the techniques we developed for CITY-seq have been successfully applied to follow-up projects. These efforts have resulted in new ways to study PPIs at much higher throughput, which aligns with the ultimate goal of this EAGER grant.

Broader Impact

This project had a significant impact on both the graduate and undergraduate students involved. The PhD student in the lab led the project, handling most of the lab work and data analysis while supervising other team members. This experience taught her important skills in project planning, allowing her to set short-term goals that supported the project’s long-term objectives. She also trained the undergraduate student in lab techniques and data analysis, guiding them through the scientific process.

The undergraduate student gained hands-on experience with proper laboratory techniques and data analysis, providing their first exposure to scientific research. Both students are female scientists, a group that is still underrepresented in genomics technology development.

Throughout the project, the PhD student had plenty of opportunities to learn how to plan and lead a research initiative while taking on supervisory responsibilities. Regular meetings with the PI provided her with feedback, allowing her to discuss challenges and future plans.


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Marko Jovanovic
